Title: Retinal ganglion cell apoptosis and neuroprotection
Source: The Curated Reference Collection in Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Psychology
Abstract: © 2016 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.Retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) relay visual information from photoreceptors (via bipolar and amacrine intermediate neurons) via the propagation of action potentials through RGC axons, which collectively transmit visual information along the optic nerve to the brain. RGC loss is associated with various optic neuropathies, including; Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, optic neuritis, anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, and glaucoma. The most prevalent of these disorders is glaucoma, a major cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. This article will explore the challenges involved in unravelling the complexities of RGC apoptosis and neuronal cell death in the context of glaucoma including a discussion of recent progress towards the development of more effective treatment strategies.
